This is the worst game I have ever played. Loathe doesn’t begin to describe how I feel about this game.Before I continue, note that I am not talking about component quality and all that – that stuff was fine. This is only a review of the game itself.This game is a frustration simulator.So you’re looking at this game and it sounds kinda fun. You play as little robots roaming around doing a relay race, fighting each other and trying to collect flags before everyone else. Sounds fun, if a little boring due to there not being a story or even much of a theme, right?Well, then you start playing it and realize that the main point of the game is frustrating your opponents. Ok, I guess that’s fine – other games have done that and it can be pretty amusing right? At least it will be a fun mindless way to watch components going at it on the board, right? Wrong. The game is in no way mindless. You have to carefully plan out 5 turns in advance on a constantly shifting board full of hazards and other players, where any one mistake can essentially take you out of the race entirely. But you think, ok, well even if it is kinda frustrating and I have to plan out that far in advance, at least I know what I’m going to be able to do – at least we are all capable of the same moves, right? Wrong. You get a random assortment of cards to build your turn out of, and whatever the deck pukes out at you is what you have to deal with to do your carefully planned and maneuvers through a randomly changing landscape where any minor mistake can take you out of the game. Fine, you might think, there are plenty of games where dealing with randomness is part of the fun. At least in those games, everyone is equal under the eyes of the randomness gods, right? Wrong again! Depending on the setup, you might start out something like 20 spaces further away from the first flag than other players. In a game where you move -1 to 3 spaces at once, and is a race, and has random card draw, and heavy planning, and take that.Ok, you think, but at least the other players are all in the same boat – it’s not like there’s yet another layer of the rich get richer going on, right? Wrong again. There are cards, which while difficult to acquire, give player powers so ridiculously powerful that they can just completely change the whole game, and make it nearly impossible to beat them.Ok, but there can’t be anything else wrong with it right? Right? Wrong, unless you like losing your turn and watching everyone else play. A lot. Fall off the edge of the map? Lose the rest of your turns for the round. Somebody kills you? Lose the rest of the turns for the round. Someone has a special remote control power card that takes over your vehicle? Lose your turn for the rest of the round AND watch as someone else pilots your robot for you. Make one tiny mistake? Get stuck on a conveyor belt that takes you so far away from where you are going that you might as well not play anymore.Let’s say things aren’t going great for you – you made a mistake and went off course, and while everyone else is working on flag 2, you still need to get to flag one. So you almost make it back when… someone kills you. Now, if you’d ever actually gotten to flag 1 your could respawn there – a little behind but not out of the pack. But you never got to flag 1. So you have to go back to where you started. You know, that spot 20 spaces further away from flag 1 than some of the other players. Oh and that’s after losing all your actions for the rest of the round.You think, fine, well, whatever, at least it’ll be over and you can do something else after. Depending on how much time you have, wrong again. This thing is going to take 2 hours. 2 hours of random upon random upon hateful take-that upon uneven starting positions upon random and you are going to lose turns all the time.Oh, and lest we forget, on top of all that, you can get cards “locked” so that you never get to choose which command to enter for certain points along your program until you either die or skip your entire turn again.Maybe it’s just me though – the other players in the group seemed to like it a lot. Maybe I’m just a sore loser who just doesn’t “get” it. Honestly though, I never blamed the actions of the other players. The game itself is a frustration simulator, so when someone kicks you in the balls when you are down, that’s really how the game is supposed to work. They might even be doing it by accident.One of the players in the game said that it was a great simulation of programming. He and I are both programmers, and I would have to strongly disagree, unless when he programs the following conditions are true: 1. You only ever have access to 5 - 9 keys on the keyboard at any one time. Many times this includes the arrow keys. No mouse.2. Those keys change every 5 minutes. You always know what the keys are, but you have to deal with what you have.3. The cursor moves randomly across the page due to powers you have no control over but if you are very careful and thoughtful you can predict.4. You are competing with other people that have various parts of the program already done before you start. 5. If you mess up, the program you are working on shuts down and it only autosaves every 20 minutes, and only then if you’ve reached some kind of minimum checkpoint.6. At random you have to sit there and do nothing for 5 minutes.7. Sometimes the keys get stuck and they will keep pressing on their own no matter what you do.8. The keyboard spins around in circles.9. You can’t get up for 2 hour stretches. Ok so maybe that is better than actual programming 10. And finally, someone keeps coming up behind you and slapping you upside the head.

In his defence most of Germany once believed electing Hitler wasn't the worst idea.

I kept reminding myself of that fact to keep my sanity relatively intact as I felt my entire world crumble around me during an extended session of what I feel is a torturous example of what the blackest minds of human society can construct.

I hate this game. To begin, simultaneous programming isn't my favourite genre. I find it tedious. It fits the theme, except I don't care about the theme if the game isn't much fun, and RoboRally isn't. There's way too much downtime which is only exacerbated by the need to miss a turn every so often, sometimes twice in a row, and there may be nothing you can do about it. That's a lot of sitting and watching other people play. It's too chaotic to hold my interest and too long for me to enjoy the ride. And it's awfully boring once you know who's (not) going to win. As with demolition derbies themselves, I'm bewildered by RoboRally's following.

I've played games that were worse from a purely technical standpoint, but on a gut level, no game has aroused as much loathing and revulsion in me as this ultra-chaotic, headache-inducing nightmare. The special weapons are unbalanced, there's a colossal runaway loser problem, you can sit and rotate all day long because you never get dealt any move cards, and it's well within the realm of possibility for a player to get eliminated 20 or 30 minutes into a game that goes on for another hour, or more. The only blessing is that you can legally commit suicide and remove yourself from the agony. There is absolutely no way I will ever play this again.

3 órás, 8 fős játék után azt mondom: nagyon jól indult, nagyon nagy reményekkel vágtam neki és hatalmas csalódás lett belőle. Az első 30-40 perc izgalmas, vicces. Még mindenkinek van 7-9 kártyája, még mindenki nagyjából egy helyen van, ha valaki "meghal", visszatérve nem érzi azt, hogy annyira le lenne maradva. Ha még ugyanennyit játszva véget ért volna (bár így is nagyon rosszul álltam), akár 2-3 ponttal is többet kapott volna. Ehelyett a következő 2 óra azzal telt, hogy egymásra vártunk, nehézkes volt a játék, aki meghalt nagyon messze a többiektől éledt újra. Óriásian befolyásolta a játék kimenetelét a kézben lévő lapok...

Ami a legnagyobb hibája a játéknak: nincs eldöntve, hogy partijáték, aminek izgalmasnak, szórakoztatónak és gyorsnak kellene lenni, vagy inkább stratégia játék, aminél fontos szerepet játszik, hogy mit lépnek a többiek, de ha jó játékos vagy, meg tudod nyerni. Nos ezek semelyike nem illik a RoboRallyra. A kártyák szerencsefaktora hatalmas, akár köröket kihagysz rossz kártyákkal, sőt sok esetben "öngyilkosságot" követsz el velük... Ha ki akarsz kerülni a rossz helyzetből sokat kell agyalnod rajta, hogy milyen sorrendben játszd ki a kártyákat, ami alatt a többiek csak várakoznak, és zavaró, hogy mindenki rám vár, dehát mit tudok tenni, ha nem jó sorrendet állítok fel, kiesek, meghalok...Amennyiben 1 órás lenne, ezeket a hátrányokat elnézném neki, sőt élvezném is, de 3-4 órát (3 óra volt az elsőből a 2. pontba eljutnia az első játékosnak!!!!) rászánni egy ilyen szerencsefüggő játékra, nagyon sajnálok...

A hangulat, a robotfigurák, a viszonylag hamar elsajátítható szabályok előnyére válnak a játéknak, de ennyi.

I really struggle with games of this type. And it's not just that I'm not good at them--after all, it could be a lot of fun to just watching your robot fail miserably. I enjoy Tales of the Arabian Nights and Galaxy Trucker, both of which can be painfully punishing and both lack any sort of agency. But with Robo Rally, you have to do the brain-burning part which is required to program your cards. Then you have certain terrain features that throw a huge wrench into not just your plans, but also your ability to even comprehend what will happen even if no other robots' actions inerfere. It took me almost the entire game to finally understand how the conveyor belts affect your movement and facing--the rules are needlessly complicated. And while there is no player elimination (at least in this version), you will have turns that are completely wasted where you did abosultely nothing.
Perhaps it would be a little bit better if players had different objectives to pursue. As it is, with every player chasing the same objective, whoever manages to get there first and get out ahead will likely leave the remaining players in the dust to fight amongst themselves--which is what happened in our game. There is no catch-up mechanism. In fact, there is a strong positive loop bc the player in the lead who hasn't been damaged still draws all their cards and keeps their special ability. The other players have fewer cards to work with and possibly have lost their unique ability.
Overall, I just struggle to find anything fun with games that require this much spatial reasoning.

So, er, *this* is the pet project that Richard Garfield was so adamant to see published that he created Magic: The Gathering just to get in the good graces of a publisher, huh. My inner Garfield fanboy kept me interested in RoboRally longer than I should have been, but it's hard to turn a blind eye on a bunch of issues that simply don't meet my modern standards:

• RoboRally is unpredictably chaotic. Like, "you're trying to (re)program a command line with your random hand of cards against other players' random hidden-until-the-last-second plays" level of chaotic.
• Now as a counterpoint, that players play cards simultaneously and face down is probably a boon when it comes to fluidifying the game. But that's because oh boy does the whole thing suffer from a sluggish pace. Between the constant brain burn of the planning phase and the fine print of the priorities when it comes to the execution of command lines, what we're essentially having here is a video game (which would no doubt feature some helpful "show me the current prospect consequences" UI) that got slowed down to an analog use-your-brain-to-parse-everything slog for no good reason.
• The game tends to develop an early runaway leader (or loser). This gets even worse if the race track is not meticulously crafted to have competitors cross paths as often as possible.
• The entire fun of the game occurs when problems happen to you. In other words, the more you're winning, the more it's a result of boring decisions with no interference.

I played this with 8 people and it took almost 7 hours. While there were things I liked about it - mostly the planning and visualization of my long term route and my individual turn), this game is un-playable unless you put some sort of time restriction on the participants.

The boards also have graphics which show when certain hazards are active, and these graphics are difficult to see. Additionally, with so many option cards and such a variety of obstacles there are way too many excursions rules (and then to the internet) to figure out what happens when Option Card Z meets up with Obstacle Q.

There aren't many games that I wouldn't play again, but I can't see another session of this in my future (certainly not without time restricting the moves). The ideal time restriction for this game would involve something like a chess clock that would give everyone, say, 20 minutes total for all their turns. That way, if you were in a complicated situation you could take a little longer to plan the possibilities, but you'd have to make it up later.

Fairly fun party game. Once someone takes the lead, they tend to run away with it for the rest of the game. For me, treating it as a party game, this doesn't kill the fun of navigating the map as long as course is short, but others may find this a problem.

The one problem I have with RoboRally is the constant shuffling and dealing of cards. This doesn't normally bother me in a card game like Hearts, so I'm not sure why it does in RoboRally: perhaps it's the frequency, perhaps it's due to having to work around the huge player mats and course boards, or perhaps it's the feeling that the shuffling and dealing is repeatedly interrupting a single continuous race, whereas in Hearts it punctuates distinct rounds.

I get with this game is trying to be, but its basic design is fundamentally flawed.

Players focus should fundamentally be about tactically navigating the obstacles and other players, and finding delight and horror in the unexpected results of their carefully laid plans--er, programs. It's a great premise.

But instead, because the results of the execution are entirely make or break, and the game is structured with nether wiggle room nor time pressure, players and up having to focus on tediously analyzing every sequence of moves. This is especially glaring when it comes to rotating conveyor belts, since the specific sequence of when you reach a square and when it turns you has such a profound impact. That means that instead of racing across the stage in a state of flow, the game continually grinds to a halt so that players don't experience frustrating, pointless mistakes of anticipating the precise order with which different pressures are applied.

I don't have a clear fix, but if this were my game, I would continue to develop it and experiment with elements of chance and error correction so that there is still depth of tactics and risk of failure, but less danger of being tripped up by an edge case of the order with which events are executed within a turn. I think you should also completely get rid of turning conveyor belts.

I would also do some work to expand the range of boards and scenarios. Currently, the very simplest boards would take a group of three players more than an hour of painstaking move execution to get through. Why not have a few radically simple starter boards?

A promising game, just not really a finished one.

This seemed like a really cool idea for a game - I had played a similar 1991 Macintosh computer game a few years before this came out, called Robosport (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RoboSport) but no one I played Roborally with, including me, actually enjoyed it. It has a serious runaway leader problem, and the random actions once you are damaged make the game increasingly one of pure process with little decision making. Sold off long ago because it just sank when actually played.

Programming is an interesting challenge, even if your plans are often sabotaged by the chaos that happens once all players execute their programming - something that you can plan for to some extent. However, the wacky gameplay and overall destruction will get tiresome pretty fast, so I recommend small maps and maps where you have to move back and forth, for a more laid back party game. Larger maps will lead to dragging game time and people playing just to finish. Plus you might get eliminated and have to wait for the rest of the group.

This edition seems better than the 2016 one which adds even more random elements and chaos.

Don't have too many players or the game will drag.
Don't have too few players or the game will be boring.
Don't prepare a full sized course or the game will go too long and there will be a runaway leader.
Don't prepare too small of a course or the game will be entirely chaos.
Don't play a full game, just stop when someone gets far enough ahead since no one will catch them anyway.
Don't play by the rules as written, play this custom variant instead.

Sometimes older designs have enough charm, elegance, or other elements where you can look past their shortcomings, but I can't see many instances where I'd want to play this again.

It's robots! Moving across a booby-trapped map! There are lasers and drills and battering rams, oh my! What could go wrong?

Well . . . quite a bit, actually. For my money, RoboRally does so very many things right - fantastic art, great design, lots of variety and replay value - but then stumbles into a major, if not exactly fatal, flaw.

One of my most important metrics in evaluating a non-cooperative game - and I recognize many others may simply not feel this way - is how well it engages the player(s) who is losing the worst. Does the last place player feel the compulsion to press on, grasping at the slim chance of victory, or out of sheer enjoyment? Or do they just feel like participation is a waste of time?

RoboRally falters badly on this score. Simply put, if you get off to a bad start in this game (which can happen due to your own incompetence, opponent machinations, or random chance), you might as well pack it up. I've never played a game that is more punishing for its lagging players, with the possible exception of Diplomacy. Moreover, because you simply respawn upon dying, you can never simply die with dignity (or hilarity).

When a game of RoboRally is going well, it can be tremendous fun - it is intense without being tense, competitive without being hostile. But when it goes badly, which happens all too often, there is too broad a "spread" between the front of the line and the back of the pack to make it enjoyable. That flaw bars RoboRally from the ranks of the regular favorites.

I love playing this game; I'm a bit of a geek for the Robot Wars TV show, and this definitely gives me those vibes. I also love the absolute chaos in this game; you can meticulously plan your move out, only to have it completely thwarted by an opponent, of often even by your own miscalculation.

Unfortunately though, I struggle to recommend it; Colt Express manages to implement the same core mechanic and provide the same feeling while playing, but in a game which is much shorter, much less fiddly to set up, and much more easily accessible to new players. Sadly I can't see any reason for buying RoboRally over Colt Express, as the latter just does everything that little bit better.

I'm still going to hold on to this game on my shelf for those few occasions when I have a group of people who are all extremely familiar with Colt Express and want a new challenge, but I know those times are going to be few and far between.

With games like this, it's best to vet your opponents, and don't invite those who are lacking good spatial visualization, as their programming can lead to feelings of frustration at unintended positioning, even when not interacting with other robots. With the right attitude, they may laugh it off, but that's not the same as enjoying the game.

Good players will estimate degrees of success stemming from possible outcomes; anticipating the chosen path of other players' robots is vital to avoid having your robot's program interrupted. You should also embrace the potential for such interaction. When it occurs, sometimes with disastrous results, you're usually faced with two options: determine whether there is sufficient time to pursue your previous goal, or go on the offensive and set back the lead player, preferably the one that pushed/redirected/exploded you off the board.

Some players can't see these tactical aspects beyond the haze of "too random" mechanics. Perhaps, if they muddle through a few plays, their perspective will change. Consider assessing these things before you sit down with new players.

Many people really don't like this game and more than any other game I've played it seems like publishers are determined to keep reworking the rules to make it appeal to newer audiences.

Don't take it too seriously and stop before people get bored.

This is a great game. Appropriate for kids and adults, it combines visual thinking and algorithmic thinking. You program a robot to move through a maze full of obstacles and dangers. If your robot moves off course (say it's pushed by another robot, or you miscalculated how fast it would move on a conveyer belt), who knows where it will end up.

The game is endlessly customizable (to the point where same more sample setups would be useful), and you will never play the same game twice.

The main problem with this game is that it is fairly unbalanced, and a lot of the features never get used. There are option cards which can add a lot of fun to the game, but they're so hard to get they almost never come up. Also since there is an advantage to being far away from the other players, if anyone jumps out to an early lead, they usually end up keeping that lead and winning.
Such fun with a lot of people in the past, not sure it would stand up today. Score is for past me.

Robo Rally ist ein Rennspiel, in dem man seinen Roboter von Runde zu Runde programmieren muss, ihn damit über das Spielfeld fahren lässt um am Ende schneller als alle Konkurrenten an den aufgestellten Fahnen zu sein.
Die Spieler erhalten am Anfang jeder Runde eine Anzahl von Bewegungskarten, die sich nach dem aktuellen Schaden des eigenen Roboters richtet. Dann programmieren alle Spieler mit diesen Karten gleichzeitig ihren Zug in die 5 Slots des eigenen Tableaus. Wer das am schnellsten macht, dreht die Sanduhr um und alle anderen Spieler haben noch knappe 30 Sekunden Zeit selbst fertig zu werden.
In der zweiten Phase werden die programmierten Karten eine nach der anderen abgearbeitet und die Roboter bewegen sich entsprechend auf dem Spielbrett. Es kann hierbei auch vorkommen, dass sie sich gegenseitig verschieben oder mit ihren Lasern Schaden zufügen, dann kommt die geplante Programmierung ganz schön durcheinander!
Ich finde das Spiel sehr gut. Ein kleines Manko dabei ist aber, dass alle Spieler ihre Karten von einem gemeinsamen Nachzugstapel erhalten und so kann es vorkommen, dass einzelne Spieler nur Rotationskarten, Andere dafür nur Bewegungskarten erhalten und somit eine ganze Runde unspielbar wird, im Extremfall wird man sogar von einem Förderband in ein Loch verschoben, wenn man keine Karten erhält um von diesem herunterzufahren. Wer in ein Loch fällt verliert Eines von drei Lebenspunkten und muss nochmals von Vorne anfangen!
Die Neuauflage des Spiels soll dieses Manko bereinigen, indem jeder Spieler ein eigenes Kartendeck erhält.
Dennoch ist das Spiel Großartig und ich spiele es jederzeit und immer wieder gerne.

Una figata pazzesca!!! Geniale! Veloce ed immediato. E' frenetico, caotico/imprevedibile e diverso ad ogni partita. In sostanza bisogna ragionare come dei veri programmatori dotati di logica... finquando qualcun'altro non vi tira lo scherzetto sballando del tutto i vostri piani, oppure "Ohh No! Mi sono confuso... Dove sto andando?". Grasse risate e colpi di scena! Adatto a tutti i tipi di giocatori, anche se ovviamente un gruppo di BASTARDI si esprime al meglio. Permette di giocare fino ad otto giocatori. C'è la componente fortuna ma è più che surclassata dalla classe che richiede giocare bene e senza prevedibilità. Componenti molto belli (bellissime miniature), la varietà degli scenari, sono tutti elementi che lo rendono unico e dalla longevità infinita. Che cosa altro dire? Può risultare un po' antipatico quando non escono le carte... macchissenefrega! Una pecca, chi rimane indietro difficilmente recupera. Peccato che sia difficile da reperire la miglior edizione, quella della Avalon Hill con sfondo nero. Mito e Leggenda.
